channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Pandemic Erased Two Decades of Progress in Math and Reading
item.description: The results of a national test showed just how devastating the last two years have been for 9-year-old schoolchildren, especially the most vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The declines in the national test scores spanned almost all races and income levels and were markedly worse for the lowest-performing students.

item.title: Witness to the Massacre in Mariupol
item.description: Survivors describe the defining atrocity of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: James Verini
item.media:credit: Paolo Pellegrin/Magnum, for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elyzaveta Fatayeva and her mother, Oksana, who now live in a suburb of Frankfurt.

item.title: Portugal Could Hold an Answer for a Europe Captive to Russian Gas
item.description: Long cut off from the continent’s grid, Portugal and Spain built a system based on imports and alternatives like solar that is the envy of fellow European Union nations.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Matilde Viegas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind turbines at work in Sintra, Portugal.

item.title: Trump’s Special Master Request Left Him Open to Justice Dept. Strike
item.description: A legal back-and-forth produced a straightforward narrative of how Mr. Trump and his lawyers repeatedly dodged the government’s attempts to recover sensitive documents for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department used a routine court filing to disclose new evidence that former President Donald J. Trump and his legal team may have interfered with the inquiry.

item.title: Trump’s Lawyers Renew Push for Special Master in Documents Inquiry
item.description: A filing claimed that the Justice Department was criminalizing the former president’s possession of “his own presidential records,” a stance at odds with the Presidential Records Act.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Donald J. Trump outside the Federal District Court in West Palm Beach, Fla., where a hearing is scheduled for Thursday.

item.title: Why Do Some People in New Jersey Suddenly Have So Many Reusable Bags?
item.description: A ban on single-use plastic and paper bags in grocery stores had an unintended effect: Delivery services switched to heavy, reusable sacks — lots of them.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Brian Otto
item.media:description: Brian Otto’s pile of reusable bags, not being reused.

item.title: Mary Peltola, a Democrat, Defeats Sarah Palin in Alaska’s Special House Election
item.description: Ms. Peltola notched a major upset against Ms. Palin and will finish the remaining four months of the term of Representative Don Young, who died in March.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Peltola’s victory in Alaska adds to a series of recent wins for Democrats.

item.title: Biden’s Message Shifts From Compromise to Combat Ahead of Midterms
item.description: President Biden is spending less time hailing the virtues of unity and more time calling out Republicans and dangers to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden is hoping that his party can maintain control of Congress and deliver a forceful rebuke to former President Donald J. Trump and his followers.

item.title: Biden to Address Threats to Democracy in Philadelphia Speech
item.description: The prime-time speech comes amid deep national divisions. According to a recent poll, nearly three-quarters of Americans believe the nation is heading in the wrong direction.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., on Tuesday. His speech Thursday in Philadelphia will be his second visit to Pennsylvania in three days.

item.title: Serena Williams’s Magical Run at the US Open Isn’t Over Yet
item.description: If two nights earlier was about posterity and sweet send-offs, Round 2 was about doing everything possible to win a tennis match, as Williams beat the world No. 2, Anett Kontaveit, in three sets.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: From Start to Finish, Venus and Serena Williams Always Had Each Other
item.description: Since the Williams sisters first burst into tennis in the 1990s, their legacy has been tied to one another. They will play doubles in perhaps the final tournament of their careers.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Earl Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Venus Williams, right, won seven Grand Slam singles titles to Serena’s 23. They paired for 14 major titles playing doubles together.

item.title: ‘I’m Just Serena,’ Swinging Freely for Another Grand Slam Run
item.description: Of course Serena Williams is confident. She deserves to be. And her opponents know that her improving game and overwhelming crowd support make beating her in this U.S. Open all the more difficult.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams, when she needed it the most against Anett Kontaveit, pumped herself up with by shouting: “Come on!”

item.title: China May Have Committed ‘Crimes Against Humanity’ in Xinjiang, U.N. Says
item.description: The organization’s human rights office delivered its much-delayed report minutes before Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, was to leave office.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press
item.media:description: A security guard at a detention center in Yarkant County, Xinjiang, China, last year. Delays to the U.N. report about abuses in the region prompted fierce pushback from rights groups.

item.title: For Uyghurs, U.N. Report on China’s Abuses Is Long-Awaited Vindication
item.description: The report’s assessment that China’s crackdown in Xinjiang could amount to “crimes against humanity” gives new momentum to a campaign to pressure Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uyghur supporters at a 2019 rally in Washington calling for sanctions against China.

item.title: Tech Companies Slowly Shift Production Away From China
item.description: Worried about geopolitical tensions and stung by pandemic shutdowns, Google, Apple and others are moving some work to nearby countries.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Quang Chau Industrial Park, which includes Foxconn factories, in Bac Giang Province, Vietnam.

item.title: U.S. Restricts Sales of Sophisticated Chips to China and Russia
item.description: Limits were placed on high-end GPUs that power supercomputers and artificial intelligence, said Nvidia and AMD, two Silicon Valley chip makers.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia is the largest maker of the newly restricted chips, known as graphics processing units, which Advanced Micro Devices also sells.

item.title: Lea Michele Is Well Aware That the Pressure Is On
item.description: She’s landed her dream role in “Funny Girl.” Now she’s tasked with rescuing the faltering Broadway show and proving that she is not the person she once was.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Gioncarlo Valentine for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I feel more ready than I ever have before, both personally and professionally,” said Lea Michele, who is set to make her first “Funny Girl” appearance on Tuesday.

item.title: The People’s Republic of Shein
item.description: Shein continues its rise with American shoppers, who don’t mind the controversies.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Cooper Neill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers lined up a 6 a.m. for a chance to shop at the Shein pop-up in Plano, Texas.

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Everyone
item.description: Our democracy sprouts in the nursery of public schools — where students grapple, together, with our messy history and learn to negotiate differences.
item.dc:creator: Anya Kamenetz
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Ansel Adams, Esther Bubley, Warren K. Leffler and Russell Lee, via Library of Congress; Museums Victoria, Muhammad Haikal Sjurki, Note Thanun and the New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons.

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Merit
item.description: Merit demands excellence and rigor. It is not, as its critics often insist, an elitist, classist or racist value.
item.dc:creator: Asra Q. Nomani
item.category: Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology (Fairfax, Va)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; photos-public-domain.com; Sam Samannejad and Gabriela Testa, via Unsplash; and Calsidyrose, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Making Citizens
item.description: Public education requires lessons about history and also contact with and context about other Americans: who we are and what has made us.
item.dc:creator: Heather C. McGhee and Victor Ray
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Library of Congress; AlexMSchool, Calsidyrose and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons; and Mika Baumeister and Dima Shishkov, via Unsplash.

item.title: ‘Defund the Police’ Is Dead. Now What?
item.description: Have we simply become inured to police shootings? Do these lives no longer matter?
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Eze Amos/Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Richmond, Va., in 2020.

item.title: Mikhail Gorbachev’s True Legacy
item.description: He was a rock star for a nation at rock bottom.
item.dc:creator: Serge Schmemann
item.media:credit: Georges De Keerle/Hulton Archives/Getty Images

item.title: Why NASA Wants to Go Back to the Moon
item.description: Why NASA wants to go back now.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Bill Ingalls/NASA
item.media:description: The rocket for the Artemis I mission, on launchpad at Kennedy Space Center.

item.title: How Gorbachev Changed the World
item.description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev set out to reform the Soviet Union. But the social and economic forces he unleashed ended up destroying it.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Jessica Cheung, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Vitaly Armand/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Gorbachev’s leadership ushered in the end of the Cold War and transformed the map of Europe, changing the world. It is a world that Mr. Putin is now at war against.

item.title: Summer’s Last Gasp Has Arrived
item.description: Our last newsletter edition of the season focuses on summer missions accomplished and those still on the to-do list.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the sun slowly sets on summer, it’s not too late to finish off those activities still on your checklist.

item.title: In Track and Field, Money Flows to the Flashy and Stylish
item.description: Winning is important when it comes to making a living in the sport. But so is finishing in style.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:credit: Kai Pfaffenbach/Reuters
item.media:description: Usain Bolt of Jamaica smiles while winning the 100-meter semifinal sprint at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: The Anglican Church’s ‘Kick in the Guts’ to Gay Parishioners
item.description: Divisions over the acceptance of homosexuality have proved intractable both on a global level and inside even liberal-leaning countries like New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Gareth Fuller/Press Association, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Justin Welby, center, the global leader of the Anglican Church, leading the opening service at Lambeth in Kent, England, on July 31.

item.title: An Apple Watch for Your 5-Year-Old? More Parents Say Yes.
item.description: As Apple prepares to unveil new models next week, the smart watch has found an unexpected audience: children as young as 5.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang and Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Florian Fangohr with his son, Felix, who said he actually wanted a smartphone. “But the watch is still really, really nice,” the 8-year-old said.

item.title: How Reagan and Bush Overcame Their Skepticism of Gorbachev
item.description: Mr. Gorbachev was charming and presented himself as a modernizer, but neither Ronald Reagan nor George Bush was convinced he was for real. They would both be proved wrong.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Paul Hosefros/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ronald Reagan and his successor, Vice President George Bush, with the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Governors Island in December 1988.

item.title: Brandon Nimmo’s Catch Helps Mets Beat Dodgers
item.description: Jacob deGrom dominated, Brandon Nimmo made a catch to remember and Timmy Trumpet played a live version of Edwin Díaz’s entrance song during a thrilling win.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Adam Hunger/Associated Press
item.media:description: Brandon Nimmo of the Mets was able to pull back a would-be home run from Justin Turner of the Dodgers on Wednesday.

item.title: Does CBD Help With Insomnia?
item.description: The research is sparse, experts say, but there are some hints about how it could soothe you to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: How to Stop Snoring: Solutions and Remedies
item.description: This sleep-disrupting problem can be caused by a variety of things, but experts say there are ways to find relief.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
item.description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Why Do I Feel Sick Before My Period?
item.description: Researchers don’t fully understand the menstrual cycle’s effects on the immune system, but experts say there are reasons some may feel sick at certain points.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Preventative’ Botox: Do Injections Work to Reduce Wrinkles?
item.description: Or are injections just a temporary, addictive fix?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: A Leading Choreographer Joins the War Effort, With Classical Ballet
item.description: Alexei Ratmansky, one of the most important figures in ballet, is supporting Ukraine by staging “Giselle” with a company made up of Ukrainian refugees.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss
item.media:credit: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexei Ratmansky at a rehearsal of “Giselle,” which is being danced by a newly formed company of Ukrainian dancers who have fled the war.
